intro: Gilia aggregata var. maculata, commonly known as the spotted gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a herbaceous annual with slender, branching stems and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The leaves are opposite, lance-shaped, and often have a hairy texture. Its flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. The plant is adapted to arid environments and is often found in disturbed soils along roadsides and in desert scrub habitats.
